message.content: This question requires understanding of the relationship between mass and gravitational force. According to Newton's law of universal gravitation, the gravitational force between two objects is directly proportional to the product of their masses. Therefore, if the mass of a celestial body is increased, it will also increase its gravitational force. Option (A) is incorrect because increasing mass does not affect the rotation of a celestial body. Option (B) is incorrect because increasing mass actually enhances the gravitational force. Option (D) is incorrect because the gravity of a celestial body is directly related to its mass, so increasing the mass will result in a stronger gravitational force.

This question requires understanding of the relationship between mass and gravity. According to the law of universal gravitation, the gravitational force between two objects is directly proportional to the mass of both objects. Therefore, if you increase the mass of a celestial body, it will also increase its gravitational force. Option (A) is incorrect because increasing the mass of a celestial body will not impact its rotation. Option (B) is incorrect because increasing the mass will actually increase the gravitational force. Option (D) is incorrect because maintaining its gravity implies that there is no change, but increasing the mass will result in an increase in gravitational force.

This question requires some basic knowledge about the effects of mass on gravity. Increasing the mass of a celestial body will result in an increase in its gravitational force. This is because gravity is directly proportional to mass, meaning that as mass increases, so does the gravitational force. Option (A) is incorrect because increasing the mass does not affect the rotation of a celestial body. Option (B) is incorrect because increasing the mass actually increases the gravitational force. Option (D) is incorrect because maintaining gravity is not a direct consequence of increasing the mass, but rather a fundamental property of all celestial bodies.

This question requires some understanding of basic physics and the concept of gravitational force. According to Newton's law of universal gravitation, the gravitational force between two objects is directly proportional to their masses. Therefore, if you increase the mass of a celestial body, it will gain gravitational force. Option (A) is incorrect because increasing mass does not affect rotation. Option (B) is incorrect because increasing mass actually increases gravitational force. Option (D) is incorrect because maintaining gravity is not a result of increasing mass, but rather a fundamental characteristic of all objects with mass.

Option (B) is incorrect because increasing the mass actually increases the gravitational force. Option (D) is incorrect because maintaining gravity does not depend on changing the mass.

This question is related to the laws of physics, specifically the law of universal gravitation. According to this law, the gravitational force between two objects is directly proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them.

So, if you increase the mass of a celestial body, it will increase its gravitational force. This means that the celestial body will have a stronger pull on other objects around it. Option (A) is incorrect because increasing the mass of a celestial body does not have any direct effect on its rotation. Option (B) is incorrect because increasing the mass actually results in a stronger gravitational force. Option (D) is also incorrect because increasing the mass does not change the fundamental nature of gravity but rather strengthens its effects.
